subject: Re: [junit] a test framework to codify levelizaton?
msgSnippet: ... Re: the Jena figures I quoted earlier, the 50 seconds reported time (now down at 45 after I shifted set implementations) is for 3729 tests, where test
messageBody:
On Monday 19 July 2004 15:01, Vlad Roubtsov wrote:
> I've waited to get some data from others before
> replying. It appears that what I had in mind were
> testcases more functional in nature. In my experience
> on a ~1GHz desktop a testsuite with 100-200 testcases
> will take from 2 to 5 minutes. This translates into
> 1-2 seconds per testcase.

Re: the Jena figures I quoted earlier, the 50 seconds reported time
(now down at 45 after I shifted set implementations) is for
3729 tests, where "test" means "invocations of a JUnit testZZZ()
method". By running outside Eclipse I appear to be able to shave
another 5s off the reported time.

Some of the tests are more multi-facteted than I'd really like, such as:

public void testRemove()
{
testRemove( "S ?? ??", "S ?? ??" );
testRemove( "S ?? ??", "?? P ??" );
testRemove( "S ?? ??", "?? ?? O" );
testRemove( "?? P ??", "S ?? ??" );
testRemove( "?? P ??", "?? P ??" );
testRemove( "?? P ??", "?? ?? O" );
testRemove( "?? ?? O", "S ?? ??" );
testRemove( "?? ?? O", "?? P ??" );
testRemove( "?? ?? O", "?? ?? O" );
}

which is really nine tests, but the tedium of writing a separate test
method for each overwhelmed me, and they are linked. Hmm.
Perhaps I should write some Javadoc for the otherwise slightly
impenetrable:

public void testRemove( String findRemove, String findCheck )
{
Graph g = getGraphWith( "S P O" );
ExtendedIterator it = g.find( Triple.create( findRemove ) );
try
{
it.next(); it.remove();
ExtendedIterator ut = g.find( Triple.create( findCheck ) );
assertFalse( ut.hasNext() );
}
catch (UnsupportedOperationException e)
{ assertFalse( g.getCapabilities().iteratorRemoveAllowed() ); }
}

And why didn't I use .contains() rather than the .find() / .next() idiom,
eh?

Always worth revisiting code ...

--
Chris "electric hedgehog" Dollin
